{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox member of the Knesset | image= יובל שטייניץ.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|4|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ramot HaShavim]], Israel | Year of Aliyah = | death_date = | Knesset(s) = [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|15]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2003|16]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|17]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|18]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2013|19]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|20]] | party1 = [[Likud]] | partyyears1 = 1999– | minister1 = [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Minister of Finance]] | ministeryears1 = 2009–2013 | minister2 = [[Intelligence and Atomic Energy Minister of Israel|Minister of Intelligence]] | ministeryears2 = 2013–2015 | minister3 = {{nowrap|Minister of International Relations}} | ministeryears3 = 2013–2015 | minister4 = [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]] | ministeryears4 = 2013–2015 | minister5 = [[Ministry of National Infrastructures, Energy and Water Resources|Minister of National Infrastructure, Energy & Water Resources]] | ministeryears5 = 2015– }}
'''Yuval Steinitz''' ({{lang-he|יובל שטייניץ}}; born 10 April 1958) is [[Israel]]'s [[Ministry of National Infrastructures, Energy and Water Resources|Minister of Energy]], in charge of [[Israel Atomic Energy Commission]] and a member of the [[Security Cabinet of Israel|Security Cabinet]]. He is a member of the [[Knesset]] from the [[Likud]] party. He served as [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Minister of Finance]] (2009-2013) and as [[Intelligence and Atomic Energy Minister of Israel|Minister of Intelligence]] and [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Strategic Affairs]] (2013-2015). Steinitz holds a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D. in Philosophy]] and was a senior lecturer at the [[University of Haifa]].
==Life and career== Born and raised in [[Moshav]] [[Ramot HaShavim]], 30  km north of [[Tel Aviv]], he is the eldest of four children. His father, Dan, is an engineer and his late mother, Mina, was a teacher of literature and philosophy. Steinitz served in the IDF as a soldier in [[Golani Brigade|Golani infantry Brigade]] (1977-1980). He sustained a leg injury during a battle with the Syrian army when he served as a reservist, during the [[1982 Lebanon War]].<ref>[http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-news-and-politics/151414/bibis-man-on-iran A Loyal Ally to Netanyahu Moves to Center Stage as Iranian Talks Heat Up]</ref>
===Academic work=== After three years of compulsory military service, he was awarded BA and MA in Philosophy at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] with honors.<ref>[https://www.knesset.gov.il/mk/eng/mk_eng.asp?mk_individual_id_t=695 MK Yuval Steinitz in the Knesset website]</ref> His doctoral thesis ''From a Rational Point of View'' was completed at the Cohn Institute for the History and Philosophy of Science and Ideas at [[Tel Aviv University]].<ref>[http://humanities1.tau.ac.il/cohn/index.php/about/2010-10-20-20-36-18 Cohn Institute for the History and Philosophy of Science and Ideas] Tel Aviv University website {{he icon}}</ref> The thesis examined the possibility of logical arguments for the existence of God, and the rule of logical reasoning in modern science. In 1993 Steinitz was awarded the [[Alon Scholarship]], the most prestigious award for outstanding young doctors in Israel, which led to a teaching position at the [[University of Haifa]]. Steinitz was chosen two years in a row as "The outstanding Lecturer" in philosophy and the philosophy of science. In 1996 he was appointed Senior Lecturer (the Israeli parallel of a [[Academic tenure|tenured assistant professor]]).
Steinitz has published several philosophy books. The first, ''Invitation to Philosophy'' (1987), became a number one best-selling philosophy book in Israeli history, and was printed in 60 editions. Another book, ''A Logical-Scientific Missile to God and Back'' became a best seller as well and was printed in 17 editions. He also published philosophical papers in academic journals including ''[[The Philosophical Quarterly]]'', ''[[American Philosophical Quarterly]]'', ''[[International Philosophical Quarterly]]'', ''[[Religious Studies (journal)|Cambridge Religious Studies]]'', and ''[[Iyyun|The Jerusalem Philosophical Quarterly Iyyun]]''.
===Political career=== Steinitz's political involvement began in the early 1980s when he joined the '[[Peace Now]]' movement as a young student. He was injured in his leg (the same leg again) during an anti-government rally in [[Jerusalem]] in 1983, when a right-wing extremist hurled a hand-grenade into the crowd, killing peace activist [[Emil Grunzweig]].<ref name="haaretz.com">[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1142735.html 'With all guns blazing'] Haaretz</ref> His reservations about [[Oslo Accords]] signed with the [[Palestinians]], together with his concerns regarding the massive [[Egyptian Army|Egyptian military]] buildup despite the peace treaty with Israel, led him to shift to the right in 1995 and to publicly support the [[Likud]] Party.<ref>[http://www.the7eye.org.il/21392 Avi Pozen "Beaad atzuma hogenet"] The Seventh Eye, 1 May 1996</ref>
===The 15th Knesset (1999–2003)=== In [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|1999]] he was elected to the 15th Knesset on the [[Likud]] list. A year later he became a member of the [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]] and the chairman of its "Subcommittee on Defense Planning and Policy" and a member of the Constitution and Law Committee.
In 1999-2004 he served as president of Israel's Media Watch.<ref>[http://imediaw.org.il/?page_id=196 Israel's Media Watch past Leadership]</ref>
===The 16th Knesset (2003–2006)=== After being reelected to the [[Israeli legislative election, 2003|16th Knesset]], he became chairman of [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]], chairman of the "Subcommittee on Intelligence and Secret Service" and co-chairman of the "Joint Committee on Defense with the US Congress", which he established and chaired together with Senator [[Jon Kyl]].<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3366186,00.html "American senators to visit Israel"] YnetNews, 17 February 2007</ref> Right at the beginning of his tenure, Steinitz declared that the committee will cease to be "The House of Lords" and will exercise "a very proactive and effective [[parliament]]ary oversight of Israel defense establishment". This new approach has led him to a series of clashes with [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Ariel Sharon]], with [[Ministry of Defense (Israel)|Minister of Defense]] [[Shaul Mofaz]] and with [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|IDF Chief of Staff]] [[Moshe Ya'alon]].<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=814876 "Who oversees the military?"] ''Globes'', 17 July 2004 {{he icon}}</ref>
A few months later he established the "Investigation Committee for the Israeli Intelligence following the Iraq War" and appointed himself as its chairman. This was followed later on by the establishment of similar committees in [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. The committee report in 2004 sharply criticized the [[Israeli Intelligence Community]] for misleading alerting reports, following its failure to detect the non-existence of chemical weapons and ballistic missiles in Iraq before the war. Additionally, the report also criticized the failure of the Israeli intelligence to detect the [[Libya and weapons of mass destruction|Libyan nuclear program]] on time. The committee's public report included a number of specific recommendations:<ref>[https://www.knesset.gov.il/committees/eng/docs/intelligence_complete.pdf The Committee of Enquiry into the Intelligence System in Light of the War in Iraq]</ref> * Consider removing [[Unit 8200|SIGINT Unit 8200]] from the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]]'s and transform it into a civilian [[SIGINT]] authority. * Accelerate the development of the Israeli [[Reconnaissance satellite|spy satellites]] program, operated together by the IDF and the [[Mossad]]. * Providing a special program of advanced academic studies for young intelligence officers, that will include, among other areas, some philosophical background. This recommendation was implemented with the establishment of the BA and MA "[[Havatzalot Program]]". * Appointing a special intelligence secretary to the [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] with the same status as the [[Military Secretary to the Prime Minister|military secretary]].
Alongside with the above, Steinitz established a special Public Committee led by Prof. [[Amnon Rubinstein]] to examine the means to improve [[parliament]]ary oversight of the defense establishment.<ref>[http://news.walla.co.il/item/639611 recommendation: The Knesset will oversee the territories] Walla News, 13 December 2004 {{he icon}}</ref> As committee chairman often pointed to the massive [[Egyptian military]] buildup with modern American weapons. In addition, Steinitz expressed a great Support for developing the [[Israeli Navy]] into a significant strategic arm and published several articles on this issue at the [[Maarachot|Maarachot Military Journal]].<ref>[http://maarachot.idf.il/PDF/FILES/8/110348.pdf The sea as Israeli strategic depth] Maarachot, May 2002 {{he icon}}</ref>
Unlike [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]], Steinitz did support [[Ariel Sharon|Sharon]]'s [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza|2005 plan to withdrawal from Gaza]]. Yet, at the same time, he led a [[parliament]]ary battle against delivering the [[Philadelphi Route|Philadelphi Corridor]] to [[Egypt]], claiming that the Egyptians deliberately ignore [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] arms smuggling through the [[Sinai Peninsula]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101202032937/http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/pages/QAHeb.jhtml?qaNo=132 Q&A with MK Yuval Steinitz] Haaretz, 2 December 2010 {{he icon}}</ref> He also argued that the Israel-Egypt [[Philadelphi Accord|Philadelphi agreement]] might erode the [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|demilitarization of Sinai]].<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3134261,00.html Government confirms: Changes to the peace agreement with Egypt] Yedioth Ahronoth, 28 August 2005 {{he icon}}</ref>
In addition, he called for a rapid "[[Operation Defensive Shield|Defensive Shield]]" Operation in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]], prior to the Israeli withdrawal, in order to destroy the [[Hamas]] and [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine|Islamic Jihad]] rockets industry.<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3090249,00.html Steinitz: Military operation or postpone disengagement from Gaza] Ynet, 25 May 2005 {{he icon}}</ref>
In 2018, the Israeli censorship allowed the publication of the secret documents that Steinitz sent to Prime Minister Sharon and the heads of the security services and intelligence organizations - in which he indicated in the summer of 2004 the possible existence of a secret nuclear project in Syria. It turned out that Steinitz and the sub-committee he chaired were the first in Israel and in the entire Western world, who have uncovered the military nuclear project in Syria, in absolute contrast to the intelligence agencies in Israel and the world. In the summer of 2004, Steinitz asked the Mossad and the Israeli Military Intelligence Directorate to present to the sub-committee of Intelligence and Secret Services a special plan to uncovering the likely secret nuclear project in Syria. While the military intelligence ignored the warnings, the Mossad did, in fact, change its action plan according to Steinitz's report, and after three years the Mossad found proof of the existence of a nuclear plant in the process of being built in the Syrian desert, what led to the [[Operation Outside the Box|distruction of the plant by the Israeli Air Force]] in 2007.<ref>[https://www.timesofisrael.com/mks-warned-of-syrias-nuke-plans-years-before-reactor-strike-report/ MKs warned about Syria’s nuke plans years before 2007 reactor strike – report] Times of Israel, 6 June 2018</ref>
===The 17th Knesset (2006–2009)=== Steinitz was reelected to the [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|17th Knesset]] in 2006 when the [[Likud]] has lost his leading position to [[Kadima]]. As an opposition [[Knesset|MK]] became again a member on the [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]] and as the chairman of the "Subcommittee on Defense Readiness". Steinitz was [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]]'s candidate for chairman of the "[[World Likud]]" in June 2006, but he lost to MK [[Danny Danon]].
===The 18th Knesset (2009–2013)=== After being reelected to the 18th Knesset, and following the [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|Likud 2009 victory]], Steinitz was appointed [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Minister of Finance]] and a member of the inner [[Security Cabinet of Israel|Security Cabinet]] by Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]].<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1075341.html Netanyahu sworn in as Israel's prime minister] Haaretz, 1 April 2009.</ref>
He was the first Finance Minister of Israel to submit to the Knesset a two-year budget, instead of the until-then customary one-year budget. This move generated some controversy, with some accusing it of decreasing government transparency<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000555470&fid=980 Two-year budget feeds corruption] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005084121/http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000555470&fid=980 |date=5 October 2012 }}. Globes (27 April 2010). Retrieved on 9 September 2011.</ref> and others praising it for its greater efficiency.<ref>[http://frischoffthepress.com/index.php/component/content/article/69-3rd-and-long/238-a-case-study-in-success-yuval-steinitz A Case Study in Success: Yuval Steinitz] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816190157/http://frischoffthepress.com/index.php/component/content/article/69-3rd-and-long/238-a-case-study-in-success-yuval-steinitz |date=16 August 2011 }}. Frischoffthepress.com (5 October 2010). Retrieved on 9 September 2011.</ref> Since then, Israel continued with the biennial budget and became the first country in the west to institute such a policy change. In 2009, most experts in the Bank of Israel and the Ministry of Finance opposed Steinitz's move, but today the biennial budget had a wide approval among the officials in the Bank of Israel and the Ministry of Finance.
===The 19th Knesset (2013–2015)=== In the [[Israeli legislative election, 2013|19th Knesset]] Steinitz served as [[Intelligence and Atomic Energy Minister of Israel|Minister for Intelligence]], [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Strategic Affairs]] and International Relations in the [[Thirty-third government of Israel|new government]].
===The 20th Knesset (2015–)=== Steinitz was reelected to [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|20th Knesset]] and became [[Ministry of National Infrastructures, Energy and Water Resources|Minister of National Infrastructure, Energy and Water Resources]] in the [[Thirty-fourth government of Israel]].
===Legislation=== Among the laws initiated by Steinitz during his tenure as MK: * A law of three-year cooling off period for [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] generals and Heads of the [[Mossad]], [[Shin Bet]], and the [[Israel police|Police]], before they can become [[Knesset|Knesset Members]] or [[Cabinet of Israel|government ministers]].<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3375598,00.html Knesset approves 3-year cooling off period for IDF officers] YnetNews, 12 March 2007</ref> * A law regulating the research of biological pathogens (bacteria, viruses, etc.) (with MK [[Aryeh Eldad]]).<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/new-law-regulates-research-of-dangerous-bacteria-and-viruses-1.256766 New Law Regulates Research of Dangerous Bacteria and Viruses] Haaretz, 6 November 2008</ref> * A law requiring noise meters in event halls.
==Minister of Finance (2009-2013)== With the establishment of the 32nd by [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]], Steinitz was appointed [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Minister of Finance]]. He took up this position in March 2009, during the beginning of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|global economic crisis]], and after the [[Economy of Israel|Israeli economy]] already suffered from two quarters of negative [[economic growth]] which led to almost 10% [[unemployment]].<ref>[http://www.financeisrael.mof.gov.il/FinanceIsrael/docs/en/TheIsraeliLaborMarket_1999-2014.pdf The Israeli Labor Market 1999-2014] Chief Economist Department's, Ministry of Finance</ref>
After few weeks at office, Steinitz has launched an emergency plan entitled "Blima & Tnufa" (Break and Accelerate) aimed at returning the [[Israel|country]] to positive [[economic growth]], through dramatically encouraging investments in the [[Science and technology in Israel|high-tech industry]], in [[Research and development|R&D]], and in construction and [[Transport in Israel|transportation]].<ref>[http://mof.gov.il/budgetsite/economicplan/documents/program%20dealing%20with%20the%20economic%20crisis%20in%202010-2009.pdf "Blima & Tnufa"] Ministry of Finance {{he icon}}</ref> As part of the program, a "triple package deal" between the government, the [[Histadrut]] Unions Association and the [[Manufacturers Association of Israel|Israel Manufacturers Association]] was signed. The employees agreed to contribute 3.5 Billion NIS to help accelerating [[economic growth|growth]].<ref>[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART1/890/163.html "After a night of discussions the package deal is signed"] NRG, 13 May 2009 {{he icon}}</ref> In April 2009, Steinitz announced his unprecedented plan to enact the first biennial budget in Israel's history,<ref>https://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/me02392.pdf</ref> as part of his counter-crisis policy. In July 2009, the government approved the biennial budget (since then all budgets in Israel were biennial).
At the beginning of his term, Steinitz raised the VAT from 15.5% to 16.5% effectively from July 2009, but it was reduced to 16% in January 2010. In 2010 the [[Economy of Israel|Israeli economy]] has already shown the fastest growing figures in the [[western world]], with 5% growth and sharp reduction of [[unemployment]].<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/analysts-shocked-officials-gleeful-at-surging-israeli-growth-7-8-in-q4-1.343864 Analysts shocked, officials gleeful at surging Israeli growth: 7.8% in Q4] Haaretz, 17 February 2011</ref>
In April 2009 Steinitz appointed Prof. [[Omer Moav]] as head of his advisory committee. When Moav resigned a year later, Steinitz appointed Prof. [[Avi Simchon]] to the post.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000555416 Finance Minister advisor Prof. Moav quits] Globes, 27 April 2010</ref> In November 2009 Steinitz appointed [[Haim Shani]] as [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|director general]], but he resigned a year and a half later following the [[2011 Israeli social justice protests|2011 social protests]].<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/treasury-chief-haim-shani-quits-over-short-shrift-from-steinitz-1.376273 Treasury Chief Haim Shani Quits Over Short Shrift From Steinitz] Haaretz, 1 August 2011</ref> [[File:שטייניץ עם מזכ"ל ה-OECD אנחל גורייה, ינואר 2016.jpg|200px|thumb|Secretary-General of the OECD José Ángel Gurría with Steinitz in Jerusalem, January 2016]]
In 2009 Steinitz started an intensive diplomatic campaign to promote Israel's acceptance to the [[OECD]].<ref>http://www.jpost.com/Business/Business-News/PM-celebrates-Israels-OECD-accession</ref> In May 2010, after more than thirty years of failing attempts and despite strong opposition from the [[Arab World]], Israel has finally become a full member of the [[OECD]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8672304.stm OECD members vote unanimously to invite Israel to join] BBC News, 10 May 2010</ref>
In 2010 Steinitz established the Sheshinski Committee to examine ways to increase the level of taxation on [[Natural Gas]] and [[Oil field]]s.<ref>[http://www.financeisrael.mof.gov.il/FinanceIsrael/Docs/En/publications/02_Full_Report_Nonincluding_Appendixes.pdf Sheshinski Committee Report January 2011]</ref> Steinitz announced that he intended to raise the level of the over-whole "government-take" on [[Petroleum industry|gas and oil]] from 20% to around 50%-60%. This led to a very aggressive campaign against him by the energy lobby, including pressures from the [[US]] [[White House]] on behalf of the American [[Noble Energy]].<ref>http://www.the7eye.org.il/12665 {{he icon}}</ref> In 2011 Steinitz legislate the committee recommendations in the [[Knesset]], raising the "government-take" on big [[Natural gas field|gas fields]] to more than 60%.<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4017386,00.html The government approved raising the tax on gas] Ynet, 23 January 2011 {{he icon}}</ref> In addition, Steinitz has doubled the royalties paid by "[[Israel Chemicals]]" from using the [[Dead Sea]] [[natural resource]]s and cancel its historic tax exemptions.<ref>[http://www.calcalist.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3437481,00.html ICL will be entitled to special taxation track] Calcalist, 30 November 2010 {{he icon}}</ref>
Two other important committees were the "Concentration Committee" (established at winter 2011 together with PM [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Netanyahu]]), which led to unprecedented steps to reduce [[Market concentration|economic concentration]] in Israel, like enforcing separation between significant Financial and Real holdings;<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.565986 Q&A What Is Israel's New Business Concentration Law and Why Should We Care? read more: http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.565986] Haaretz, 29 December 2013</ref> And the "Investment Taxation Committee" (established in 2010 together with Minister [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer|Ben-Eliezer]]), which led to significant increase in Israel's investments incentives.<ref>[http://www.inn.co.il/News/News.aspx/199735 Ministers of Industry and Finance will examine tax incentives] Channel 7, 26 January 2010 {{he icon}}</ref>
In 2011, a doctors' strike broke out and paralyzed all Hospitals and Clinics around the country, in what became the longest strike in Israel history. The strike ended after five months with a compromise between the [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Ministry of Finance]] and the [[Israel Medical Association|Doctors union]], which included the improvement of the doctors employment conditions, especially in peripheral [[hospital]]s, as well as Steinitz's demand that hospital doctors will be subjected to time clocks. Nevertheless, hundreds of [[Internship (medicine)|interns]] and 200 senior doctors continued the strike and the protest against the deal, until eventually the protest petered out.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/israeli-doctors-strike-finally-ends-after-five-months-as-landmark-deal-inked-1.380681 Israeli Doctors Strike Finally Ends After Five Months as Landmark Deal Inked] Haaretz, 25 August 2011</ref>
In the summer of 2011, and alongside with the doctors strike, a series of social protests against the cost of living in Israel took place. Demonstrations took place for a prolonged period of time, focusing on the high housing prices and the cost of daycare. The protesters were accompanied by [[Doctor of Medicine|doctors]], [[teacher]]s, [[student]]s, and dairy farmers, who called for a change in the government social outlook.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/04/israel-protests-social-justice Israeli protests: 430,000 take to streets to demand social justice] The Guardian, 4 September 2011</ref> At the beginning Steinitz rejected the protesters' claims. But with the continuation of the protests, Steinitz began to show a more flexible attitude. One step was lowering taxes in order to reduce [[Gasoline and diesel usage and pricing|petrol price]] hike. Following the appointment of the "[[Trajtenberg Committee]]", Steinitz dealt with implementation of the committee's recommendations.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Steinitz-praises-Trajtenberg-Ctee-not-all-recommendations Steinitz praises Trajtenberg C'tee, not all recommendations] The Jerusalem Post, 28 September 2011</ref>
In September 2011, [[Standard & Poor's|S&P]] raised [[Israel]] [[credit rating]] to A+.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-09-21/israel-punches-above-weight-as-gdp-outperforms-developed-world Israel Punches Above Weight as GDP Beats Developed World] Bloomberg, 22 September 2011</ref> This decision took place in light of the fact that Israel managed to continue to reduce its debt-to-GDP ratio, and despite the global economic crisis.
During his tenure, Steinitz made extensive efforts to develop business connections with [[China–Israel relations|China]] and [[India–Israel relations|India]]. In 2010-2011, Israeli exports to these countries increased by 35%.<ref>[https://www.boi.org.il/he/NewsAndPublications/RegularPublications/DocLib3/BankIsraelAnnualReport/%D7%93%D7%95%D7%97%20%D7%91%D7%A0%D7%A7%20%D7%99%D7%A9%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%9C%202013/all-2013.pdf Annual Report 2013] Bank Of Israel, March 2013 {{he icon}}</ref> During his three official visits in [[China]] and [[India]], Steinitz led negotiations for the signing a series of bilateral agreements designed to increase the volume of trade with these countries. Among other things, the agreement include specipic steps to encourage young doctors from [[China]] and [[India]] to make their [[Postdoctoral researcher|Postdoctoral Researches]] in [[Israel]].<ref>[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/16/ART2/219/148.html Israel and India are establishing a high-tech investments fund totaling 40 Million Dollar] NRG, 7 March 2011 {{he icon}}</ref><ref>[http://news.walla.co.il/item/1892697 For the first time in a decade : Indian foreign minister visits Israel] Walla News, 10 January 2012 {{he icon}}</ref><ref>[http://cms.education.gov.il/EducationCMS/Units/Dovrut/pedagogia/haskala/shitufpeulaakademi.htm Academic cooperation with India and China] Education Ministry Spokesman, 27 February 2012 {{he icon}}</ref>
In July 2012, Steinitz led the signing of an [[Economic partnership agreement|economic agreement]] between [[Israel]] and the [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Authority]] with [[Prime Minister of the Palestinian National Authority|Prime Minister]] [[Salam Fayyad]]. As part of the deal, it was decided to increase joint enforcement against smuggling of goods, and [[Israel]]i assistance to the [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian]] tax collection capabilities.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4263166,00.html Israel, PA ink first economic deal since 2002] Ynet News, 1 August 2012 {{he icon}}</ref>
In 2012 the state [[Government budget balance|annual deficit]] reached 39 Billion NIS, almost twice as much as was predicted, but the [[Debt-to-GDP ratio]] continued to decline. The average [[economic growth]] during Steinitz's tenure as [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Finance Minister]] (2010-2012) was 4.5%, the highest economic growth in the entire developed world.
==Minister of Intelligence and Strategic Affairs (2013-2015)== After the [[Israeli legislative election, 2013|2013 elections]] Steinitz was appointed [[Intelligence and Atomic Energy Minister of Israel|Minister for Intelligence]], [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Strategic Affairs]] and International Relations, and became responsible to several topics: [[File:Israeli International Relations, Intelligence and Strategic Affairs Minister (13717279683).jpg|200px|thumb|British Foreign Secretary William Hague with Steinitz in London, April 2014]] * '''[[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran Nuclear Program]]''' - Steinitz coordinated the [[Israel]]i [[Foreign relations of Israel|diplomatic efforts]] vis-à-vis the [[P5+1]] and the rest of the international community. He met regularly with senior officials dealing with [[Iran]]ian issue including [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Joe Biden]], the Chief US nuclear negotiator with Iran [[William Joseph Burns|Bill Burns]] and [[Wendy Sherman]], and the Foreign Ministers of [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[France]], and [[Germany]]. He also met the heads of intelligence in those countries, like the heads of the [[CIA]] and [[Director of National Intelligence|DNI]] in the [[US]] or the [[MI6]] in [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. During those meetings, Steinitz emphasized the size of the threat to Israel and the whole world as a result of [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran's military nuclear program]].<ref>[http://www.dtinews.vn/en/news/017004/32199/israel-minister-meets-british-official-on-iran-deal-.html Israel minister meets British official on Iran deal] dtinews, 27 November 2013</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/24/world/middleeast/israeli-officials-talk-with-french-to-try-to-influence-iran-nuclear-deal.html Israeli Officials Talk With French to Try to Influence Iran Nuclear Deal] The New York Times, 23 March 2015</ref> In the interim Agreement he convinced the [[France|French]] delegation to insist on limiting Iranian [[Enriched uranium|Uranium enrichment]] to 3.5% level. This limitation was included in the final agreement as well. According to Steinitz, the Israeli involvement and input did have a significant impact on both the interim and [[Iran nuclear deal framework|final agreements]] with Iran.<ref>[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/193128 Intelligence Min. Wraps Up Lobbying Mission against Iran Deal] Channel 7, 24 March 2015</ref> * '''Responsibility for economic issues vis-à-vis [[Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Authority]]''' - with the resumption of negotiations with the PA, Steinitz was appointed to coordinate the [[Economy of the State of Palestine|economic issues]]. * '''Responsibility for civilian intelligence agencies, [[Mossad]] and [[Shin Bet]]'''. * '''Responsibility for the [[Israel–United States relations|US-Israel]] strategic dialogue''' - as part of the activity, Steinitz led the discussions with US officials on the cooperation on policy, military, and intelligence issues, in order to strengthen the strategic alliance between the two countries. * '''Responsibility for the [[Israel Atomic Energy Commission]]'''
==Minister of Energy and Water Resources (2015-)== In [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|May 2015]], Steinitz was appointed [[Ministry of National Infrastructures, Energy and Water Resources|Minister of National Infrastructure, Energy and Water Resources]], as well as Minister in charge of the [[Israel Atomic Energy Commission]]. Two months later, after several years of delays and against very strong opposition from the Israeli left circles, Steinitz formulated the "Gas Framework", in order to enable the development of Israel's biggest gas discovery "[[Leviathan gas field|Leviathan]]" (discovered in 2010), and to pave the way to future [[Hydrocarbon exploration|gas and oil explorations]]. The "Gas Framework" was approved by the [[Cabinet of Israel|Israeli government]] in August 2015, and by the [[Knesset]] Plenum in September 2015. Yet in March 2016 [[Supreme Court (Israel)|Israel's Supreme court]] nullified the framework stability section, and forced Minister Steinitz to amend it and bring it back to government approval. The revised framework was approved in May 2016, and the development of "[[Leviathan gas field|Leviathan]]" ultimately started.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.720888 Israeli Government Approves Revised Gas Deal] Haaretz, 22 May 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.bizportal.co.il/gazandoil/news/article/429873 Ministry of Infrastructures approved 'Leviathan' development plan] Bizportal, 2 June 2016 {{he icon}}</ref>
[[File:בעת ביקורו של מזכיר האנרגיה האמריקאי בישראל, אפריל 2016.jpg|thumb|right|220px|US Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz and Steinitz in Jerusalem, April 2016]] In April 2016 the [[United States Secretary of Energy|US Energy Secretary]] Dr. [[Ernest Moniz]] visited [[Israel]] for the first time. Together with Steinitz, they signed a bilateral agreement which upgrades the energy cooperation between the [[United States]] and [[Israel]].<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Business-and-Innovation/Environment/US-and-Israel-to-expand-energy-water-ties-amid-gas-deal-shakeup-450227 US and Israel to expand energy, water ties amid gas deal shakeup] The Jerusalem Post, 4 April 2016</ref>
In July 2016 Steinitz announced that the [[Ministry of National Infrastructures, Energy and Water Resources|Ministry of Energy]] will publish new [[oil and gas]] licenses, after four years in which the country economic waters were practically closed for new [[Hydrocarbon exploration|explorations and searches]].<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-energy-minister-israel-has-gas-reserves-worth-4-leviathans-1001132526 Israel has undiscovered gas worth 4 Leviathans] Globes, 16 June 2016</ref>
During 2017, the natural gas monopoly consisting of the Israeli company "Delek" and the American company "Noble Energy" had begun to fall apart, when the selling of the Karish-Tanin to the Greek company "Energean" occurred. This ultimately led to more competition for customers and the cheaper prices.
In April 2017 Steinitz hosted the ministers of energy from Italy, Greece, and Cyprus, as well as the European Commissioner for Energy, to kick off his plan to construct a sub-sea pipeline - the longest and deepest in the world - allowing Israel and Cyprus to export gas to Greece and Italy, and through them to west Europe.
In his capacity, Steinitz initiated a plan to eliminating the use of coal and polluting fuels in the State of Israel, and replacing them with natural gas and renewable energies. Within 3 years the percentage of coal and mazut dropped from 65% of electricity production in 2015 to 25% in 2018. According to the plan, in 2027 Israel will no longer continue to use coal. Steinitz has also promoted a plan to shift all transportation in Israel from traditional fuels to electricity and natural gas, by the year 2030.
In June 2018, Steinitz signed an implementation agreement with his American counterpart, Rick Perry, establishing a joint energy research and development center. This cooperation agreement aims to accelerate development and rapid deployment of critical and innovative technologies for natural gas, cybersecurity, energy-water nexus, water storage, and other areas of energy that are needed to diversify energy supply and promote higher efficiency.
==Views== He has campaigned for heightened awareness of the Iranian nuclear threat, lobbying at home and abroad to ensure that Iran does not become a nuclear power.<ref>Claire, Sheera. (12 November 2007) [https://archive.is/20120708173845/http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1192380792234 Steinitz: Egypt letting Hamas build an army]. ''Jerusalem Post''. Retrieved on 9 September 2011.</ref>
In 2008, when Israel refused permission for Palestinian [[Fulbright]] students to leave [[Gaza City|Gaza]] and study in the United States, Steinitz supported this action. He told the [[New York Times]]: "We are fighting the regime in Gaza that does its utmost to kill our citizens and destroy our schools and our colleges. So I don’t think we should allow students from Gaza to go anywhere. Gaza is under siege, and rightly so, and it is up to the Gazans to change the regime or its behavior."<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/30/world/middleeast/30gaza.html?pagewanted=2&ei=5087&em&en=2c197bd9044256e9&ex=1212292800 U.S. Withdraws Fulbright Grants to Gaza]. ''The New York Times''. (30 May 2008). Retrieved on 9 September 2011.</ref> He disagreed with former Governor of the [[Bank of Israel]], [[Stanley Fischer]], on various issues, and has a complicated relationship with Netanyahu, who bypassed him several times in his first year in office.<ref name="haaretz.com"/>
In June 2013, when Austria planned to withdraw its UN-Troops (stationary since 1974) from the [[Golan Heights]], Yuval Steinitz issued a statement expressing regret at the Austrian move, adding that the lesson for Israel was clear: "Even as part of peace agreements, Israel cannot place its security in the hands of international forces instead of relying on the presence of IDF soldiers."{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In December 2015, after the assassination of [[Samir Kuntar]], he claimed in the newspaper [[Haretz]] that the [[Finnish Security Intelligence Service|Finnish Intelligence services]] was perhaps behind this affair.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/1.692786</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|user=LauraHuu|author=Laura Halminen|number=678552980937920512|date=20 December 2015|title=Finnish #intelligence ? Excuse me? #israel #Finland #Kuntar}}</ref> After contact from the [[Helsingin Sanomat]] newspaper, Hareetz claimed that it was a joke, putting to serious threat Israel's foreign policy.<ref>http://www.hs.fi/ulkomaat/a1450578236902</ref>
On 19 November 2017, Energy Minister Yuval Steinitz said that Israel has had covert contacts with Saudi Arabia amid common concerns over Iran. This is the first public admission of cooperation between the two countries by a senior Israeli official.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theindependent.in/meet-the-new-friend-of-israel-saudi-arabia/|title=Meet the new friend of Israel: Saudi Arabia|date=20 November 2017|website=theindependent.in}}</ref>
On 7 May 2018, Steinitz, in an interview to Israeli news site [[Ynet]], said that Syrian President [[Bashar al-Assad]], should be '[[Assassination|eliminated]]' by Israel for his relationship with Iran, he later clarified it was his personal opinion and not that of the [[Government of Israel|government]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/israel-will-eliminate-assad-if-he-lets-iran-operate-from-syria-1.6062375|title=Israel Will 'Eliminate' Assad if He Continues to Let Iran Operate From Syria, Minister Warns|last=Haaretz|date=2018-05-07|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-05-07}}</ref>
==Family== Steinitz is married to Gila Kanfy-Steinitz, a judge and the vice president of the Jerusalem District Court. They have three children.
